review.title: Simulated Penetration Testing and Mitigation Analysis
review.abstract: Penetration testing is a well-established practical concept for the identification of potentially exploitable security weaknesses and an important component of a security audit. Providing a holistic security assessment for networks consisting of several hundreds hosts is hardly feasible though without some sort of mechanization. Mitigation, prioritizing counter- measures subject to a given budget, currently lacks a solid theoretical understanding and is hence more art than science. In this work, we propose the first approach for conduct- ing comprehensive what-if analyses in order to reason about mitigation in a conceptually well-founded manner. To evaluate and compare mitigation strategies, we use simulated penetration testing, i.e., automated attack-finding, based on a network model to which a subset of a given set of mitigation actions, e.g., changes to the network topology, system updates, configuration changes etc. is applied. We determine optimal combinations that minimize the maximal attacker success (similar to a Stackelberg game), and thus provide a well-founded basis for a holistic mitigation strategy. We show that these what-if analysis models can largely be derived from network scan, public vulnerability databases and manual inspection with various degrees of automation and detail, and we simulate mitigation analysis on networks of different size and vulnerability.

metadata.title: Simulated Penetration Testing and Mitigation Analysis

sections.text: In this paper, we propose the first approach to conducting comprehensive what-if analyses in order to make conceptually sound mitigation considerations. To evaluate and compare mitigation strategies, we use simulated penetration tests, i.e. automated attack identification, based on a network model to which a subset of certain mitigation measures, such as changes in network topology, system updates, configuration changes, etc., are applied. We identify optimal combinations that minimize maximum attack success (similar to a Stackelberg game) and thus provide a sound basis for a holistic mitigation strategy. We show that these what-if analytical models are largely derived from network scanning, public vulnerability databases, and manual inspection with varying degrees of automation and detail, and we simulate mitigation analyses on networks of varying size and vulnerability.

sections.heading: 7. Practical Model Acquisition
sections.text: The formalism and algorithm presented in the previous sections encompass a wide range of network models. In this section, we describe a highly automated approach to acquiring a particular form of such network model in practice, demonstrating that our method is easily applicable; the general workflow is similar to MulVAL [38], which integrates machine-readable vulnerability descriptions and reports from network vulnerability scanners such as Nessus to derive a simple logical model specified in Datalog. Our workflow follows the same idea, but in addition, we include possible mitigation measures described in a concise and general scheme. Furthermore, our formalism looks at the probable / uncertain nature of exploitations.4

sections.heading: 1. Scenario Generator
sections.text: The problems we generate are exactly as described in Section 7. Therefore, we describe the scenario generation in terms of topology, i.e., the network relationships defined by the network proposition subnet and connections described by the network proposition haclz, and the mapping of the configurations, i.e., the network proposition vul exists and appropriate action options. The network topology generation follows previous work on network penetration tests connected to the DMZ zone. Similar to the current example, we create networks that are divided into four zones: user, DMZ, sensitive and Internet. The Internet consists of only one host, initially under ad-serial control, which is connected to the DMZ zone. The DMZ and the sensitive zone each represent a subnet of hosts that are connected to both subnets. The user zone is a hierarchy, a tree of subnets in which each subnetwork is connected to its parent and its sensitive part.

metadata.abstractText: Penetration testing is a well-established practical concept for the identification of potentially exploitable security weaknesses and an important component of a security audit. Providing a holistic security assessment for networks consisting of several hundreds hosts is hardly feasible though without some sort of mechanization. Mitigation, prioritizing countermeasures subject to a given budget, currently lacks a solid theoretical understanding and is hence more art than science. In this work, we propose the first approach for conducting comprehensive what-if analyses in order to reason about mitigation in a conceptually well-founded manner. To evaluate and compare mitigation strategies, we use simulated penetration testing, i.e., automated attack-finding, based on a network model to which a subset of a given set of mitigation actions, e.g., changes to the network topology, system updates, configuration changes etc. is applied. We determine optimal combinations that minimize the maximal attacker success (similar to a Stackelberg game), and thus provide a well-founded basis for a holistic mitigation strategy. We show that these what-if analysis models can largely be derived from network scan, public vulnerability databases and manual inspection with various degrees of automation and detail, and we simulate mitigation analysis on networks of different size and vulnerability.
